questions.text: A newborn exhibits persistent unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that does not resolve within the first three weeks of life. Laboratory investigations reveal normal liver function tests, normal prothrombin time/international normalized ratio (PT/INR), and normal serum albumin levels. No evidence of hemolysis is found on a blood smear. After initiating phenobarbital therapy, the bilirubin levels decrease significantly within a week. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2
A form of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that shows notable improvement within 7-10 days of phenobarbital treatment is characteristic of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2. This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern and results from homozygous missense mutations in the UGT1A1 gene, leading to a partial deficiency of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation. The clinical presentation typically involves persistent unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital therapy, distinguishing it from more severe forms such as type 1.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria and proteinuria. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The boy in the above clinical scenario has the characteristic features of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP). Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. About half of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear, that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth, is found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate is 60 beats/min, and a grimace is seen with some flexion of extremities. The Apgar score for this newborn is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In this baby
• Color, blue - score 0
• Heart rate, <100 beats/min - Score 1
• Grimace-score 1
• Some flexion of the extremities - Score 1
• Irregular respiration - Score 1
Thus total score is 4

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A poor diet history (rice water) and a swollen belly are suggestive of Kwashiorkor.
Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by oedema and apathy.

choices.text: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.text: A child who has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In the given scenario, the close contact of the patient is a 3-year-old child who has received the vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. So, it is most likely that the child has received the 4th dose (1st booster) of the diphtheria vaccine. Hence, only erythromycin is indicated in this case.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The likely cause in the given clinical scenario is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), in which 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes ambiguous genitalia in females due to increased serum androgens.
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders caused by the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones in the adrenal cortex. It causes pseudohermaphroditism, that is, genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia looks like that of a male.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

questions.text: A child presents with generalised edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urine analysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The clinical scenario showing a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.
Glomerular diseases associated with heavy proteinuria clinically manifests as Nephrotic Syndrome.
The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome:
• Hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL)
• Edema
• Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL)
along with proteinuria > 3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2 to warrant a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In a child with suspected shunt-associated meningitis, the next best step useful in confirming the diagnosis is by taking a blood culture and a CSF sample from a shunt tap.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with seizures. His past history is significant for an episode of fever with rash at 1 year of age which resolved spontaneously. What is the most helpful investigation to diagnose his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
This patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), also known as Dawson disease, which is caused by infection with the measles virus. The CSF anti-measles antibodies - IgG antibodies will be elevated and hence, it is the most helpful investigation to diagnose this condition.

choices.text: Rate of increase in height and weight

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the OPD by his mother, complaining that his growth is not as much as his siblings. He is not eating well and is not as energetic with poor performance in studies and sports. The physician monitors all the aspects required for growth monitoring. Which of the following is the best indicator to monitor the child's growth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rate of increase in height and weight 
The rate of increase in height or weight as age advances is the best indicator of growth monitoring in children. One-time measurement does not indicate if the child's growth rate has been normal in the recent past. Serial measurements provide a rate of growth. Plotting growth velocity is a useful tool for the early identification of factors affecting growth. Growth monitoring is done using growth charts.

questions.text: A female infant is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child exam. The mother starts to wean her child from breastfeeding and started on semi solid foods. When the mother gave one biscuit in her baby's hand, to her surprise, the child could take the biscuit to her mouth all by herself. At what age can the child do that?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

6 months 

This is a case of a well-child examination in which the child could take the biscuit to her mouth alone. By 5- 6 months, a child can begin to take the biscuit to his mouth. By 12 months, he tries to feed herself with a cup but spills some of the contents. By 15 months, he can drink from a cup without spilling. By 18 months, he can feed himself well with a spoon

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for an 8-year-old boy with intellectual disability and abnormal facial appearance including an elongated face, large mandible, and large ear set, with a mid-systolic click, followed by a late systolic murmur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fragile X syndrome 
A child with an intellectual disability and having an abnormal facial appearance like an elongated face with large protruding ears and mid systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur heard best at the apex is suggestive of fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is accompanied to the obstetrics and gynecology OPD by her mother. The girl has not yet started menstruation. On examination, she has developed secondary sexual characteristics appropriately. The gynecologist provides counseling and reassurance to them and educates them about the stages of puberty. What is the correct sequence of events in puberty?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thelarche - pubarche - growth spurt - menarche

This sequence reflects the typical progression of pubertal development in girls.

questions.text: Which reflex was tested in a 4-month-old neonate born full-term when the doctor flexed the baby's head forwards and observed the straightening of legs and flexion of the upper extremities?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Symmetric tonic neck reflex (STNR) 
Important neonatal reflexes appearing after birth are the parachute reflex and the symmetric tonic neck reflex. When the child's head flexes forward, extending the back of the neck, the upper extremities will contract and the lower extremities will extend. Conversely, when the child's head is extended backward, contracting the back of the neck, the upper extremities will extend and the lower extremities will contract.

choices.text: Katori spoon paladai feeding or feeding

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman delivers a baby boy by a cesarean section at 27 weeks gestation. The baby weighs 1.6 kg. He did not cry soon after birth. After examination, the baby is transferred to the NICU, and the pediatrician recommends initiation of feeding. Which of the following is the best initial feeding method for this newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Preterm babies born at less than 28 weeks of gestation often exhibit inadequate sucking efforts and lack of propulsive gut motility, making enteral feeding challenging. Due to these limitations, such infants are best initially fed through intravenous fluids or total parenteral nutrition (TPN). TPN is the preferred method of feeding for preterm babies born at 27 weeks of gestation, as it ensures adequate nutrition while their gastrointestinal system is immature and not yet capable of supporting enteral feeds effectively.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male infant presenting with moderate respiratory distress, tachycardia, vomiting, absent breath sounds on the left side, displacement of the apex beat to the opposite side, and visible bowel gas above the diaphragm on chest x-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
 This is a case of congenital diaphragmatic hernia in which the patient presents with complaints of respiratory distress, tachypnea and vomiting for 3 days. Chest X-ray shows multiple air-filled cysts in the left hemithorax, the shift of the mediastinum to the right side. The absence of an outline of the left diaphragm is a suggestive sign of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Respiratory distress in the neonate. Vomiting Tachycardia Absence of breath sounds on the affected side.

questions.text: What stage of the disease, according to Modified Bell's staging, is indicated in a 19-day-old neonate with symptoms of vomiting, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, distended abdomen, and the presence of gas bubbles within the intestinal walls on an abdominal X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stage IIIb 
This is a case of necrotising enterocolitis stage IIIb in which the patient presents with complaints of vomiting, diarrhoea, fever and rectal bleeding for two days. On examination, the abdomen is distended and tender. An x-ray abdomen of the patient is done, which reveals intestinal perforation and pneumoperitoneum, which is suggestive of necrotising enterocolitis stage IIIb.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 7-month-old child presenting with diarrhea and mucocutaneous lesions that began after the initiation of weaning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acrodermatitis enteropathica 

Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis for the child's symptoms after weaning from breast milk is Acrodermatitis enteropathica. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired zinc absorption, leading to zinc deficiency. It typically manifests when breast milk or formula is replaced with a zinc-deficient diet, such as solid foods. The condition is characterized by diarrhea, skin lesions, and other mucocutaneous manifestations.
